Headline: Sales & GTM Strategy | FMCG Expert | Ex-Nestl√© |Sales Head | Profitable & Viable GTM Strategies | Trade & Shopper Marketing | Leadership & Mentorship | Recruitment Specialist | Driving Growth & Innovation
Comment:
Absolutely, Rishabh. Distribution is not an afterthought , it‚Äôs a strategic imperative . 
Of the original 4 P‚Äôs, Place often gets the least attention , ironically, it‚Äôs the one that determines whether your product even stands a chance to be discovered. In today‚Äôs fragmented landscape, with D2C, marketplaces, offline, omnichannel, and partner-led routes , how and where you reach your customer needs as much clarity as what you offer them.
A strong GTM strategy is not a scale lever. It‚Äôs a survival lever.
And I fully endorse your points , Distribution planning should start not after the product is ready, but before it is even packaged. It should influence your pricing, margins, channel mix, visibility strategy, and even your product design choices.
ZA Consulting

Headline: Angel Investor | Startup | Mentor | Investor | ESG | Geospatial | Consumer| Tech | Cypto | Web3 | Metaverse | Food | Beverage | Consumer | Restaurants
Comment:
Absolutely spot on Rishabh Mariwala.

As a food and consumer VC, I‚Äôve seen far too many pitches where distribution is an afterthought‚Äîshoehorned in after the product roadmap and packaging design. But in today‚Äôs hyper-competitive landscape, even a 10/10 product will fail if it shows up on a 2/10 channel.
I believe Before the first unit rolls off the line, founders must ask:
Where is my customer already spending attention, time, and money?
Retail shelf? Insta reel? WhatsApp group? Modern trade? Kirana stack?
Great distribution isn't built. It's understood.
